Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story: I stared at my phone, the notification for the team meeting blinking insistently. It was just a routine catch-up, nothing urgent, and I knew it would be recorded. Still, I could already imagine the subtle disappointment in my manager’s voice if I didn’t show up. At the same time, my son tugged at my sleeve, his eyes wide with anticipation. I had promised him a Nintendo if I got my bonus, and today was the day I was supposed to take him to the store. The bonus had come, but it wasn’t as much as I’d hoped. I felt the weight of our bills, the groceries, the rent, all pressing down on me. My colleagues expected me to be present, to contribute, to be a team player. My son expected me to keep my promise, to be the parent who made his day. I felt torn, the demands of work and family pulling me in opposite directions, my heart pounding as I tried to figure out which expectation I would have to let down.
